title.narrative: Conservation of 13th-16th-Century Funerary Towers of the Condor Amaya Necropolis

description.narrative: Built between 1200 and 1459, the funerary towers (chullpares) in the Condor Amaya necropolis are vulnerable to damage and deterioration from vandalism and unchecked erosion. The project includes the conservation of 21 of the towers and an inventory of associated objects.

person-name.narrative: Jenee Sharon; Wes Aviles; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Department of State, Diplomatic and Consular Programs

description.narrative: Enables UNODC to accompany provide technical support to and monitor the Bolivian government's eradication of coca crops

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

title.narrative: Conservation of the 19th-Century Bell Tower of Oruro Cathedral

description.narrative: The tower is an important architectural landmark and cultural touchstone of Oruro, Bolivia's fifth largest city. This project involves the conservation of the tower, its 17th-century bell, and its clock mechanism.

title.narrative: Preventive Conservation of Community Heritage Collections on the Qhapac an (Inca Road)

description.narrative: The Association of Representatives of Community Museums along the legendary Qhapaq an (Inca Road) is a best practice model for the collective stewardship of small indigenous heritage sites and museums in Bolivia. This project involves conservation and engagement activities at six associated community museums along the Desaguadero-Viacha section of the Qhapac an.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: Jenee Sharon; Wes Aviles; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Department of State, Diplomatic and Consular Programs
Department of State, Diplomatic and Consular Programs

title.narrative: Engaging Indigenous Women to Prevent and Counter Trafficking in Persons

description.narrative: The goal of this project is to: prepare communities, authorities, and service providers to better prevent, investigate, and respond to trafficking in persons (TIP) - primarily in target municipalities - through TIP education and training of at-risk individuals and local officials; increasing cooperation between communities, indigenous authorities, and local officials to prevent, identify, and respond to TIP cases in selected municipalities; increasing resources and assistance to victims of TIP in selected municipalities; and national dissemination of project successes and lessons learned.

person-name.narrative: Jenee Sharon; Wes Aviles; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: International Narcotics Control and Law Enforcement
International Narcotics Control and Law Enforcement

title.narrative: Conservation of 19th- and Early 20th-Century Mausoleums in La Paz General Cemetery

description.narrative: Established in 1826, the La Paz General Cemetery contains more than 140,000 tombs and mausoleums. This project involves the conservation of two mausoleums and community engagement activities.

person-name.narrative: Jenee Sharon; Wes Aviles; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Documentation of Afro-Bolivian Traditional Music and Dances

description.narrative: Traditional music and dance are an important part of Afro-Bolivian culture, but the roots of those traditions are at risk due to migration and the introduction of modern rhythms. This project involves the documentation of traditional music and dances in 15 rural communities in the Yungas.

sector.narrative: Democracy, Human Rights, and Governance - General

title.narrative: Restoration of Five 17th and 18th-Century Colonial Chapels in Curahuara de Carangas

description.narrative: To support the expansion of work begun under a previous Ambassadors Fund grant to restore Spanish colonial chapels in Curahuara de Carangas. Preserved entirely by local communities, these rural chapels are in serious danger of collapse as straw roofs, plaster, and lime-based paint deteriorate. This project involves the restoration of five chapels to their original condition using traditional materials and local labor.

participating-org.narrative: Santiago de Curahuara de Carangas Parish

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Department of State, Diplomatic and Consular Programs

title.narrative: Restoration of the Mid-18th-Century Santa Teresa Church in Cochabamba

description.narrative: One of the first convent churches in Cochabamba and the only one built in the Baroque style, the building is susceptible to damage from water infiltration and a structurally compromised roof. This project includes structural stabilization and other remedial preservation measures to keep the building dry and safe.

title.narrative: Conservation of the Mid-18th-Century Santa Teresa Convent in Cochabamba

description.narrative: Built in 1760 for the Carmelite Order, and rebuilt in 1790 after an earthquake, Santa Teresa Convent is one of Cochabambas most important landmarks. A continuation of work begun under a previous Ambassadors Fund grant, this project involves the conservation of the roof, walls, and floors of the convent.

title.narrative: Conservation of the 14th-16th-Century Samaipata Fort Archaeological Site and Associated Collections

description.narrative: Samaipata's massive carved rock formation "El Fuerte " retains evidence of pre-Inka, Inka, and Spanish colonial use of the site. This project, which includes site conservation and upgrades to the site museum, directly supports the Embassy's efforts to promote sustainable growth and the Memorandum of Understanding between the United States and Bolivia concerning the imposition of import restrictions on archaeological material from the pre-Columbian cultures of Bolivia.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: Jenee Sharon; Wes Aviles; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Department of State, Diplomatic and Consular Programs
Department of State, Diplomatic and Consular Programs

title.narrative: Conservation of Ancient Stone Sculptures at the Pre-Columbian Site of Tiwanaku

description.narrative: The former capital of a pre-Hispanic empire that covered most of the southern Andes, the ancient city of Tiwanaku remains spiritually important to Bolivias Aymara community while also attracting national and international tourists. This project involves the conservation of stone sculptures, development of new conservation practices to mitigate stone loss, training for local maintenance workers, and the digitization of the site.

participating-org.narrative: Center for Research, Archaeology, Anthropology and Administration of Tiwanaku

title.narrative: Conservation of the Mid-18th-Century Santa Teresa Convent in Cochabamba, Phase 2

description.narrative: Built in 1760 for the Carmelite Order, and rebuilt in 1790 after an earthquake, Santa Teresa Convent is one of Cochabambas most important landmarks. This project, which completes conservation work begun under previous Ambassadors Fund grants, directly supports the U.S. embassys efforts to promote sustainable economic development and the treaty between Bolivia and the United States concerning the looting and illicit trafficking of Bolivian cultural property.
